title: Fedora
data:
**[English]()** • [中文（中国大陆）‎](/wiki/Fedora/zh-CN "Fedora/zh-CN")

| \[   fedora   [![Fedora.png](/images/5/5e/Fedora.png)](/wiki/File:Fedora.png) |                                      |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------ |
| Appearance                                                                    | fedora                               |
|                                                                               |                                      |
| Slot                                                                          | [helm](/wiki/Helm "Helm")            |
| AC                                                                            | [0](/wiki/Armor_class "Armor class") |
| Special                                                                       | *(none)*                             |
|                                                                               |                                      |
| Base price                                                                    | 1 [zm](/wiki/Zorkmid "Zorkmid")      |
| Weight                                                                        | [3](/wiki/Weight "Weight")           |
| Material                                                                      | [cloth](/wiki/Cloth "Cloth")         |

A **fedora** is a type of [helm](/wiki/Helm "Helm") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is made of [cloth](/wiki/Cloth "Cloth"), and provides no AC when worn.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Origin](#Origin)

- [5 Variants](#Variants)

  - [5.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [5.2 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [5.3 xNetHack](#xNetHack)
  - [5.4 SlashTHEM](#SlashTHEM)
  - [5.5 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [6 Encyclopedia](#Encyclopedia)

- [7 References](#References)

## Generation

The fedora is not randomly generated.

The [Archeologist](/wiki/Archeologist "Archeologist") starts each game with a +0 fedora.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

## Strategy

Due to its lack of special ability, [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") benefits and even sale value, the Archeologist's starting fedora is often ditched near the beginning of the game for the first (usually [metallic](/wiki/Metallic "Metallic")) helm the player finds.

## History

The fedora first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Fedora](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fedora "wikipedia:Fedora")***

The fedora is a felt hat with a wide brim (about 2.5 inches or 6.4 cm) and a distinctive lengthwise crease in the crown; the style goes back as far as the 1880s. The name is derived from the 1882 Victorien Sardou play *Fedora*, in which actress Sarah Bernhardt (whom the play was written for) wore one while playing the titular "Princess Fedora"; the term itself would see regular use as the early 1890s. Fedoras were especially popular from the 1920s to the early 1950s, and fell out of widespread fashion after the mid-1950s - they are still occasionally seen worn as accessories in the modern day.

The *[Indiana Jones](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indiana_Jones "wikipedia:Indiana Jones")* franchise is first set in 1936, and is significantly inspired by *[Secret of the Incas](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secret_of_the_Incas "wikipedia:Secret of the Incas")* and its main character, Harry Steele - the fedora's inclusion in *NetHack* is part of the Archeologist role's homage to the series.

## Variants

Some variants play up the *Indiana Jones* homage further by making the fedora function similar to a [luck item](/wiki/Luck_item "Luck item").

In the [biodiversity patch](/wiki/Biodiversity_patch "Biodiversity patch"), a straw golem may drop an [eroded](/wiki/Eroded "Eroded") fedora upon death.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), the fedora increases [charisma](/wiki/Charisma "Charisma") by 1 and prevents good [Luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck") from timing out when worn, in the same way a blessed [luckstone](/wiki/Luckstone "Luckstone") does.

[Upgrading](/wiki/Upgrading "Upgrading") a fedora will produce an [elven leather helm](/wiki/Elven_leather_helm "Elven leather helm"), and vice versa.

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), the fedora increases base Luck by 1 for Archeologists when worn;[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) they can also safely enchant one at a maximum of +5. In addition, a fedora may be found along with an [archeologist](/wiki/Archeologist_\(player_monster\) "Archeologist (player monster)") [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") under a [rolling boulder trap](/wiki/Rolling_boulder_trap "Rolling boulder trap").

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), Archeologists can safely enchant fedoras from a maximum of +5, and there is a chance of finding one on an archeologist corpse in the path of a rolling boulder trap - both changes were adapted from UnNetHack.

### SlashTHEM

In addition to SLASH'EM details, [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM") incorporates the biodiversity patch, including straw golems dropping an eroded fedora upon death.

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), upgrading a fedora will produce an elven helm and vice versa, as in SLASH'EM.

## Encyclopedia

Some hats can only be worn if you're willing to be jaunty, to set  
them at an angle and to walk beneath them with a spring in your  
stride as if you're only a step away from dancing. They demand a  
lot of you.  
 \[Anansi Boys, by Neil Gaiman]

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/u\_init.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 33](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/u_init.c#L33)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/timeout.c in UnNetHack revision 1499, line 197](http://sourceforge.net/p/unnethack/code/1499/tree/trunk/src/timeout.c#l197)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")
html:
Fedora

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
English

 • 中文（中国大陆）‎
[   fedora  
Appearance fedora
Slot helm
AC 0
Special (none)
Base price 1 zm
Weight 3
Material cloth

A fedora is a type of helm that appears in NetHack. It is made of cloth, and provides no AC when worn.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Origin
  • 5 Variants
    • 5.1 SLASH'EM
    • 5.2 UnNetHack
    • 5.3 xNetHack
    • 5.4 SlashTHEM
    • 5.5 Hack'EM
  • 6 Encyclopedia
  • 7 References

Generation

The fedora is not randomly generated.

The Archeologist starts each game with a +0 fedora.[1]

Strategy

Due to its lack of special ability, AC benefits and even sale value, the Archeologist's starting fedora is often ditched near the beginning of the game for the first (usually metallic) helm the player finds.

History

The fedora first appears in NetHack 3.0.0.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Fedora

The fedora is a felt hat with a wide brim (about 2.5 inches or 6.4 cm) and a distinctive lengthwise crease in the crown; the style goes back as far as the 1880s. The name is derived from the 1882 Victorien Sardou play Fedora, in which actress Sarah Bernhardt (whom the play was written for) wore one while playing the titular "Princess Fedora"; the term itself would see regular use as the early 1890s. Fedoras were especially popular from the 1920s to the early 1950s, and fell out of widespread fashion after the mid-1950s - they are still occasionally seen worn as accessories in the modern day.

The Indiana Jones franchise is first set in 1936, and is significantly inspired by Secret of the Incas and its main character, Harry Steele - the fedora's inclusion in NetHack is part of the Archeologist role's homage to the series.

Variants

Some variants play up the Indiana Jones homage further by making the fedora function similar to a luck item.

In the biodiversity patch, a straw golem may drop an eroded fedora upon death.

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, the fedora increases charisma by 1 and prevents good Luck from timing out when worn, in the same way a blessed luckstone does.

Upgrading a fedora will produce an elven leather helm, and vice versa.

UnNetHack

In UnNetHack, the fedora increases base Luck by 1 for Archeologists when worn;[2] they can also safely enchant one at a maximum of +5. In addition, a fedora may be found along with an archeologist corpse under a rolling boulder trap.

xNetHack

In xNetHack, Archeologists can safely enchant fedoras from a maximum of +5, and there is a chance of finding one on an archeologist corpse in the path of a rolling boulder trap - both changes were adapted from UnNetHack.

SlashTHEM

In addition to SLASH'EM details, SlashTHEM incorporates the biodiversity patch, including straw golems dropping an eroded fedora upon death.

Hack'EM

In Hack'EM, upgrading a fedora will produce an elven helm and vice versa, as in SLASH'EM.

Encyclopedia

Some hats can only be worn if you're willing to be jaunty, to set
them at an angle and to walk beneath them with a spring in your
stride as if you're only a step away from dancing. They demand a
lot of you.
 [Anansi Boys, by Neil Gaiman]

References

  1. ↑ src/u_init.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 33
  2. ↑ src/timeout.c in UnNetHack revision 1499, line 197

A '''fedora''' is a type of [[helm]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. It is made of [[cloth]], and provides no AC when worn.

==Generation==
The fedora is not randomly generated.

The [[Archeologist]] starts each game with a +0 fedora.{{refsrc|src/u_init.c|33|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

==Strategy==
Due to its lack of special ability, [[AC]] benefits and even sale value, the Archeologist's starting fedora is often ditched near the beginning of the game for the first (usually [[metallic]]) helm the player finds.

==History==
The fedora first appears in [[NetHack 3.0.0]].

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Fedora}}
The fedora is a felt hat with a wide brim (about 2.5 inches or 6.4 cm) and a distinctive lengthwise crease in the crown; the style goes back as far as the 1880s. The name is derived from the 1882 Victorien Sardou play ''Fedora'', in which actress Sarah Bernhardt (whom the play was written for) wore one while playing the titular "Princess Fedora"; the term itself would see regular use as the early 1890s. Fedoras were especially popular from the 1920s to the early 1950s, and fell out of widespread fashion after the mid-1950s - they are still occasionally seen worn as accessories in the modern day.

The ''[[wikipedia:Indiana Jones|Indiana Jones]]'' franchise is first set in 1936, and is significantly inspired by ''[[wikipedia:Secret of the Incas|Secret of the Incas]]'' and its main character, Harry Steele - the fedora's inclusion in ''NetHack'' is part of the Archeologist role's homage to the series.

==Variants==
Some variants play up the ''Indiana Jones'' homage further by making the fedora function similar to a [[luck item]].

In the [[biodiversity patch]], a straw golem may drop an [[eroded]] fedora upon death.

===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], the fedora increases [[charisma]] by 1 and prevents good [[Luck]] from timing out when worn, in the same way a blessed [[luckstone]] does.

[[Upgrading]] a fedora will produce an [[elven leather helm]], and vice versa.

In [[UnNetHack]], the fedora increases base Luck by 1 for Archeologists when worn;{{refsrc|src/timeout.c|197|unnethack=1499}} they can also safely enchant one at a maximum of +5. In addition, a fedora may be found along with an [[archeologist (player monster)|archeologist]] [[corpse]] under a [[rolling boulder trap]].

===xNetHack===
In [[xNetHack]], Archeologists can safely enchant fedoras from a maximum of +5, and there is a chance of finding one on an archeologist corpse in the path of a rolling boulder trap - both changes were adapted from UnNetHack.

===SlashTHEM===
In addition to SLASH'EM details, [[SlashTHEM]] incorporates the biodiversity patch, including straw golems dropping an eroded fedora upon death.

===Hack'EM===
In [[Hack'EM]], upgrading a fedora will produce an elven helm and vice versa, as in SLASH'EM.
